question_text: How do infrequent bursts of black carbon production in flare plumes affect the statistical distribution of species concentration ratios, and what implications does this have for accurately measuring combustion efficiency?
standard_answer: Infrequent bursts of black carbon (BC) production in flare plumes create positively skewed statistical distributions in species concentration ratios like BC/H₂O. These bursts populate the long tail of the distribution and have an outsized influence on the mean value. The skewed distribution means that a single measurement would most probably return the mode of the distribution, which was approximately 13% less than the mean for both types of flare gas tested. This statistical behavior calls into question the assumption that species concentration ratios used to derive combustion efficiency are highly correlated and fixed. Inadequate sampling that misses these infrequent high-emission events would cause combustion efficiency estimates to be biased toward higher values, as the measurement would capture the more frequent low-emission periods while missing the bursts that substantially reduce global efficiency. The positive skewness observed in BC/H₂O ratios suggests that BC/CO₂ ratios would follow similar trends, introducing considerable uncertainty into measurements that assume fixed concentration ratios.
